p: Across sites, protected clutches had a mean size of 160.2 ± 37.8 eggs (range = 3–274, n = 2,031), a mean hatching success of 56.8 ± 30.2% ( n = 2031), and produced 185,922 hatchlings. Hatching success was lower in clutches protected in situ (43.6 ± 30.0%, n = 153) than those relocated on the beach (46.2 ± 32.2%, n = 124) and in hatcheries (58.6 ± 29.7%, n = 1757). There were larger clutches and lower hatching success at Bahía de Jiquilisco than Estero Padre Ramos (Table 2), with significant differences in hatching success among nest protection strategies and years at both sites (Table 4). At Bahía de Jiquilisco, hatching success was significantly higher ( t = 2.4390, df =833, p = 0.0149) during the first half (55.7 ± 31.8%, n = 559) than the second half (49.7 ± 35.8%, n = 276) of the nesting season, whereas at Estero Padre Ramos, it was only slightly higher ( t = 1.3734, df = 1,197, p = 0.1699; first half, 60.6 ± 26.8%, n = 679; second half, 58.4 ± 28.5%, n = 520).
